text: After the death of Joshua, the Israelites inquired of Yahweh, saying, “Who will go up first for us against the Canaanites to fight against them?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said, “Judah will go up. I hereby give the land into his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judah said to Simeon his brother, “Go up with me into my allotment, and let us fight against the Canaanites; then I too will go with you into your allotment.” And Simeon went with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judah went up, and Yahweh gave the Canaanites and the Perizzites into their hand, and they defeated ten thousand men at Bezek.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Bezek they came upon Adoni-bezek, and they fought against him and defeated the Canaanites and the Perizzites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Adoni-bezek fled, but they pursued after him; they caught him and cut off his thumbs and big toes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoni-bezek said, “Seventy kings with their thumbs and big toes cut off used to pick up scraps under my table; just as I have done, so God has repaid to me. And they brought him to Jerusalem, and he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Judah fought against Jerusalem, and they captured it, put it to the sword, and set the city on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward the descendants of Judah pursued to fight against the Canaanites who were living in the hill country, the Negev, and the Shephelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judah went against the Canaanites living in Hebron (the former name of Hebron was Kiriath Arba). And they defeated Sheshai, Ahiman, and Talmai.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from there they went to the inhabitants of Debir (the former name of Debir was Kiriath Sepher).
speaker: Narrator

text: And Caleb said, “Whoever attacks Kiriath Sepher and captures it, I will give to him Acsah my daughter as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Othniel son of Kenaz, the younger brother of Caleb, captured it, and he gave to him Acsah his daughter as a wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she came to him, she urged him to ask her father for a field. As she dismounted from the donkey, Caleb said to her, “What do you want?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to him, “Give me a gift; you have given me the land of the Negev, and give me also a spring of water.” And Caleb gave to her the upper and lower spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Hobab the Kenite, Moses’ father-in-law, went up with the descendants of Judah from the city of palms into the wilderness of Judah, which is in the Negev near Arad. And they went and settled with the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Judah went with his brother Simeon, and they defeated the Canaanites inhabiting Zephath; they utterly destroyed it, so he called the name of the city Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah captured Gaza and its territory, Ashkelon and its territory, and Ekron and its territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh was with Judah, and he took possession of the hill country, but they could not drive out the inhabitants of the plain because they had chariots of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: They gave Hebron to Caleb just as Moses said, and he drove out the three sons of Anak from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the descendants of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem, so the Jebusites have lived among the descendants of Benjamin in Jerusalem to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise, the house of Joseph went up against Bethel, and Yahweh was with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the house of Joseph spied out Bethel (the former name of the city was Luz).
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the spies saw a man leaving the city, they said to him, “Please show us the entrance of the city, and we will deal kindly with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he showed them the entrance of the city, and they struck the city with the edge of the sword, but they let go the man and all his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the man went to the land of the Hittites, and he built a city and named it Luz; this is its name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh did not drive out Beth-Sean and its towns, or Taanach and its towns, or the inhabitants of Dor and its towns, or the inhabitants of Ibleam and its towns, or the inhabitants of Megiddo and its towns; the Canaanites were determined to live in this land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it happened, when Israel grew strong, they put the Canaanites to forced labor, but they never totally drove them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites living in Gezer, so the Canaanites lived in their midst in Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron or Nahalol, so the Canaanites lived in their midst and became subjected to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, Sidon, Ahlab, Aczib, Helbah, Aphik, or Rehob,
speaker: Narrator

text: so the Asherites lived in the midst of the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land, for they did not drive them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naphtali did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth Shemesh or Beth-anath, but lived in the midst of the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land; the inhabitants of Beth Shemesh and Beth-anath became forced labor for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Amorites pressed the descendants of Dan to the hill country, and they did not allow them to come down to the plain;
speaker: Narrator

text: the Amorites were determined to live in Har-heres, in Aijalon, and in Shaalbim, but the hand of the house of Joseph was heavy on them, and they became subjected to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The border of the Amorites ran from the ascent of Akrabbim from Sela and upward.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the angel of Yahweh went up from Gilgal to Bokim and said, “I brought you up from Egypt, and I brought you to the land that I had promised to your ancestors. I said, ‘I will never break my covenant with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for you, do not make a covenant with the inhabitants of this land; break down their altars.’ But you did not listen to my voice. Why would you do such a thing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I say, I will not drive them out from before you; they will become as thorns for you, and their gods will be a trap for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And as the angel of Yahweh spoke these words to all the Israelites, the people wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they called the name of this place Bokim, and there they sacrificed to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua sent the people away, and the Israelites went each to their own inheritance to take possession of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people served Yahweh all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua, who saw all the great work Yahweh had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joshua son of Nun, servant of Yahweh, died at the age of one hundred and ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried him within the border of his inheritance in Timnah-heres, in the hill country of Ephraim north of Mount Gaash.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, that entire generation was gathered to their ancestors, and another generation grew up after them who did not know Yahweh or the work he had done for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh, and they served the Baals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They abandoned Yahweh the God of their ancestors, who brought them out from the land of Egypt. They followed other gods from the gods of the people who were around them; and they bowed down to them, and they provoked the anger of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: They abandoned Yahweh, and they served Baal and the Ashtaroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the anger of Yahweh was kindled against Israel, and he gave them into the hand of plunderers; and they plundered them, and he sold them into the hand of their enemies from all sides. They were unable to withstand their enemies any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever they went out, the hand of Yahweh was against them to harm them, just as Yahweh warned, and just as Yahweh had sworn to them. And they were very distressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh raised up leaders, and they delivered them from the hand of their plunderers.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen to their leaders, but lusted after other gods and bowed down to them. They turned away quickly from the way that their ancestors went, who had obeyed the commandment of Yahweh; they did not do as their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Yahweh raised leaders for them, Yahweh was with the leader, and he delivered them from the hand of their enemies all the days of the leader, for Yahweh was moved by their groaning because of their persecutors and oppressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the leader died they relapsed and acted corruptly, more than their ancestors, following other gods, serving them, and bowing down to them. They would not give up their deeds or their stubborn ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the anger of Yahweh burned against Israel, and he said, “Because this people transgressed my covenant that I commanded their ancestors, and have not obeyed my voice,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not again drive out anyone from before them from the nations that Joshua left when he died,
speaker: Narrator

text: in order to test Israel whether or not they would observe the way of Yahweh, to walk in it just as their ancestors did.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh left those nations; he did not drive them out at once, and he did not give them into the hand of Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the nations that Yahweh left, to test Israel by them (that is, to test all those who had not experienced any of the wars of Canaan,
speaker: Narrator

text: in order that the generations of Israel would know war, to teach those who had not experienced it before):
speaker: Narrator

text: the five rulers of the Philistines, all the Canaanites, the Sidonians, and the Hivites living on Mount Lebanon, from Mount Baal Hermon up to Lebo-Hamath.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were left for testing Israel, to know whether they would keep the commands of Yahweh that he commanded their ancestors through the hand of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites lived in the midst of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they took their daughters as wives for themselves, and they gave their daughters to their sons, and they served their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh. They forgot Yahweh their God, and they served the Baals and the Asheroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the anger of Yahweh was kindled against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of Cushan-Rishathaim, the king of Aram Naharaim; and the Israelites served Cushan-Rishathaim eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites cried out to Yahweh, and Yahweh raised up a deliverer for the Israelites who delivered them, Othniel son of Kenaz, Caleb’s younger brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the spirit of Yahweh came upon him, and he judged Israel. He went out to war, and Yahweh gave Cushan-Rishathaim king of Aram into his hand, and he prevailed over Cushan-Rishathaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the land rested forty years. Then Othniel son of Kenaz died.
speaker: Narrator

text: And again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh. So Yahweh strengthened Eglon king of Moab against Israel, because they did evil in the eyes of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gathered to himself the Ammonites and Amalekites, and he went and defeated Israel, and they took possession of the city of palms.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites served Eglon king of Moab eighteen years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites cried out to Yahweh, and Yahweh raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud son of Gera, a Benjaminite and a left-handed man. And the Israelites sent a tribute to Eglon king of Moab through him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud made for himself a short, two-edged sword (a cubit in length), and he fastened it under his clothes on his right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he presented the tribute to Eglon king of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ehud had finished presenting the tribute, he sent away the people who carried the tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he turned back from the sculptured stones that were near Gilgal, and he said, “I have a secret message for you, O king.” And he said, “Silence!” So all those standing in his presence went out,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ehud came to him while he was sitting alone in his cool upper room. And Ehud said, “I have a message from God for you.” So he got up from his seat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ehud reached with his left hand for the sword on his right thigh, and he thrust it into his stomach.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the handle also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade because he did not draw back the sword from his stomach; and it went protruding out the back.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ehud went out the vestibule, and he closed the doors of the upper room and locked them behind him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he left, his servants returned. When they saw that the doors of the upper room were locked, they thought, “Surely he is relieving himself in the cool inner room.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they waited so long they became embarrassed because he did not open the doors of the upper room. So they took the key and opened the doors, and there their lord was lying on the ground dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ehud escaped while they delayed. He passed by the sculptured stones and escaped to Seirah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he arrived he sounded the trumpet in the hill country of Ephraim, and the Israelites went down from the hill country with him leading them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to them, “Follow after me! Yahweh has given Moab your enemies into your hand.” So they went down after him, and they captured the fords of the Jordan toward Moab; and they did not allow anyone to cross over.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they struck Moab at that time, about ten thousand men, all strong and able men; no one escaped.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moab was subdued on that day under the hand of Israel. And the land rested eighty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Shamgar son of Anath came after him, and he killed six hundred Philistines with the goad of an ox; he also delivered Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And again the Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh, and Ehud died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh sold them into the hand of Jabin king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. The commander of his army was Sisera, and he was living in Harosheth Haggoyim.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites cried to Yahweh, as he had nine hundred iron chariots, and he oppressed the Israelites cruelly for twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now at that time Deborah, a prophetess, the wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she used to sit under the palm tree of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim; and the Israelites went up to her for judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: She sent and called for Barak son of Abinoam from Kedesh Naphtali and said to him, “Has not Yahweh the God of Israel commanded you? ‘Go, march to Mount Tabor, and take ten thousand men from the descendants of Naphtali and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will draw out Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and troops, to the wadi of Kishon, and I will give him into your hand.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak said to her, “If you go with me, I will go; but if you do not go with me, I will not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Surely I will go with you; however, there will be no glory for you in the path you are taking, for Yahweh will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman.” And Deborah stood up and went with Barak to Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barak summoned Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh; and they went up behind him, ten thousand men, and Deborah went up with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Heber the Kenite was separated from the other Kenites, that is, from the descendants of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses. And he was encamped at Elon-bezaanannim, which is near Kedesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they reported to Sisera that Barak son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sisera summoned all his chariots—all nine hundred chariots of iron—and the entire army that was with him from Harosheth Haggoyim to the wadi of Kishon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Deborah said to Barak, “Get up! This is the day that Yahweh has given Sisera into your hand. Has Yahweh not gone out before you?” So Barak went out from Mount Tabor with ten thousand men following him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh threw Sisera and all his chariots and army into confusion before the edge of Barak’s sword; and Sisera dismounted from his chariot and fled on foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Barak pursued after the chariots and army as far as Harosheth Haggoyim, and all of Sisera’s army fell to the edge of the sword; no one was left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sisera fled on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, because there was peace between Jabin king of Hazor and the house of Heber the Kenite.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jael came out to meet Sisera, and she said to him, “Turn aside, my lord; turn aside to me and do not be afraid.” So he turned aside into her tent, and she covered him with a blanket.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to her, “Please, give me a drink of water, because I am thirsty.” So she opened a skin vessel of milk and gave him a drink and covered him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to her, “Stand at the doorway of the tent, and if anyone comes and asks you, and says, ‘Is there anyone here?’ You must answer, ‘No.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, took in her hand a tent peg and a hammer, and she went softly to him and drove the peg into his temple, and it went through into the ground; he was fast asleep since he was exhausted, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: And behold, Barak was pursuing Sisera, and Jael went out to meet him, and she said to him, “Come, and I will show you the man whom you are seeking.” And he came with her and saw that Sisera was lying dead with the peg in his temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day God subdued Jabin king of Canaan before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the hand of the Israelites pressed harder and harder on Jabin king of Canaan, until they destroyed Jabin king of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang on that day:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When long hair hangs loosely in Israel,
    when the people willingly offer themselves,
        bless Yahweh!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, O kings! Give ear, O princes!
    I will sing to Yahweh;
    I will sing praise to Yahweh,
        the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yahweh, when you went down from Seir,
    when you marched from the region of Edom,
the earth trembled, the heavens poured down,
    the clouds poured down water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountains trembled before Yahweh,
    this Sinai, at the presence of Yahweh, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In the days of Shamgar son of Anath,
    in the days of Jael, the caravans had ceased,
    the travelers, they kept to the byways.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God chose new leaders,
    then war was at the gates;
a small shield or a spear was not seen
    among forty thousand in Israel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The riders of white female donkeys,
    those sitting on saddle blankets,
        and those going on the way, talk about it!
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the sound of those dividing the sheep
        among the watering places,
    there they will recount the righteous deeds of Yahweh,
    the righteous deeds for his warriors in Israel.
Then the people of Yahweh went down to the gates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Wake up, wake up, Deborah!
    Wake up, wake up, sing a song!
Get up, Barak!
    Take captive your captives, O son of Abinoam.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the remnant went down to the nobles;
    the people of Yahweh went down for him against the mighty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Why do you sit among the sheepfolds,
    to hear the calling sounds of the herds?
For the clans of Reuben,
    there were great searchings of the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gilead has remained beyond the Jordan.
    Why did Dan dwell as a foreigner with ships?
Asher sat at the coast of the waters,
    and by his coves he has been settling down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zebulun is a people who scorned death,
    and Naphtali, on the heights of the field.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The stars fought from heaven;
    from their courses they fought against Sisera.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wadi torrent of Kishon swept them away,
    the raging wadi torrent,
        the wadi torrent of Kishon.
    March on, my soul, with strength!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then the hooves of the horse beat loudly,
    because of galloping, galloping of his stallions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Curse Meroz,’ says the angel of Yahweh;
    ‘curse bitterly its inhabitants,
because they did not come to the help of Yahweh,
    to the help of Yahweh against the mighty.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He asked for water, and she gave milk;
    in a drinking bowl for nobles, she brought curds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She reached out her hand to the peg,
    and her right hand for the workman’s hammer;
and she struck Sisera, crushed his head,
    and she shattered and pierced his temple.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Through the window she looked down;
    the mother of Sisera cried out through the lattice,
‘Why is his chariot delayed in coming?
    Why do the hoof beats of his chariot tarry?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wisest of her ladies answer her;
    she also answers the question herself:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Are they not finding and dividing the plunder?
    A bedmate or two bedmates for every man;
colorful garments for Sisera,
    plunder of colorful garments,
beautifully finished colorful garments,
    on the neck of the plunderer?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So may all your enemies perish, O Yahweh,
but those who love him are like the rising sun at its brightest.”
And the land had rest for forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh, and Yahweh gave them into the hand of the Midianites for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hand of the Midianites prevailed over Israel; because of the presence of the Midianites, the Israelites made for themselves hiding places that were in the mountains, caves, and strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whenever Israel sowed seed, the Midianites, Amalekites, and the people of the east would come up against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would camp against them and destroy the produce of the land as far as Gaza; they left no produce in Israel, or sheep, ox, or donkey.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they, their livestock, and their tents would come up like a great number of locusts; they and their camels could not be counted; they came into the land and devoured it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel was very poor because of the presence of the Midianites, and the Israelites cried out to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites cried out to Yahweh on account of the Midianites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh sent a prophet to the Israelites, and he said to them, “Thus says Yahweh the God of Israel: ‘I brought you up from Egypt; I brought you from the house of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: I delivered you from the hand of Egypt and from the hand of all your oppressors, and drove them out from before you; and I gave you their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said to you, ‘I am Yahweh your God; do not fear the gods of the Amorites, in whose land you are living.’ But you have not listened to my voice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of Yahweh came and sat under the oak that was at Ophrah that belonged to Jehoash the Abiezrite; and Gideon his son was threshing wheat in the winepress to hide it from the Midianites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of Yahweh appeared to him and said to him, “Yahweh is with you, you mighty warrior.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said to him, “Excuse me, my lord. If Yahweh is with us, why then has all this happened to us? Where are all his wonderful deeds that our ancestors recounted to us, saying, ‘Did not Yahweh bring us up from Egypt?’ But now Yahweh has forsaken us; he has given us into the palm of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh turned to him and said, “Go in this your strength, and you will deliver Israel from the palm of Midian. Did I not send you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Excuse me, my lord. How will I deliver Israel? Look, my clan is the weakest in Manasseh, and I am the youngest in my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said to him, “But I will be with you, and you will defeat Midian as if they are one man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to him, “Please, if I have found favor in your eyes, show me a sign that you are speaking with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please, do not depart from here until I come back to you and bring out my gift and set it out before you.” And he said, “I will stay until you return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon went and prepared a young goat and unleavened cakes from an ephah of flour; he put meat in a basket, and the broth he put in a pot, and he brought them to him under the oak and presented them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of God said to him, “Take the meat and the unleavened cakes and put them on this rock; pour the broth over it.” And he did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of Yahweh reached out the tip of the staff that was in his hand, and he touched the meat and the unleavened cakes; and fire went up from the rock and consumed the meat and the unleavened cakes. And the angel of Yahweh went from his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon realized that he was the angel of Yahweh; and Gideon said, “Oh, my lord Yahweh! For now I have seen the angel of Yahweh face to face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said to him, “Peace be with you. Do not fear; you will not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon built there an altar to Yahweh, and he called it “Yahweh is peace.” To this day it is still in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on that same night Yahweh said to him, “Take the bull of the cattle that belongs to your father, and a second bull seven years old, and pull down the altar of Baal that belongs to your father, and cut down the Asherah that is beside it;
speaker: Narrator

text: and build an altar to Yahweh your God on the top of this stronghold in the proper arrangement, and take a second bull and offer it as a burnt offering with the wood of the Asherah that you will cut down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon took ten men from his servants, and he did just as Yahweh told him; and because he was too afraid of his father’s family and the men of the city to do it during the day, he did it during night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of the city got up early in the morning, look, the altar of Baal and the Asherah that was beside it were cut down, and the second bull was offered on the altar that had been built.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to one another, “Who did this thing?” So they searched and inquired, and they said, “Gideon son of Jehoash did this thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of the city said to Jehoash, “Bring out your son so that he may die, for he has pulled down the altar of Baal and cut down the Asherah that was beside it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoash said to all who stood against him, “Will you contend for Baal? Will you rescue him? Whoever contends for him will be put to death by the morning. If he is a god, let him contend for himself because his altar has been pulled down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus, on that day he was called Jerub-Baal, which means, “Let Baal contend against him,” because he had pulled down his altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the Midianites, Amalekites, and the people of the east gathered together and crossed the Jordan; and they camped in the valley of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Spirit of Yahweh took possession of Gideon, and he blew on the trumpet, and the Abiezrites were called to follow him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent messengers throughout all Manasseh, and they were also called to follow him; and he sent messengers throughout Asher, Zebulun, and Naphtali, and they went up to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon said to God, “In order to see that you will deliver Israel by my hand, just as you have said,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will place a fleece of wool on the threshing floor. If there is dew on the fleece only, and all of the ground is dry, I will know that you will deliver Israel by my hand, just as you have said.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was so. He arose early the next day and squeezed the fleece, and he wrung out dew from the fleece, a full drinking bowl of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon said to God, “Do not let your anger burn against me; let me speak once more. Please let me test once more with the fleece; let the fleece be dry, and let there be dew on the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And God did so that night; only the fleece was dry, and dew was on all the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) rose early, and all the army that was with him. They were camped beside the spring of Harod; the camp of Midian was north of the hill of Moreh, in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said to Gideon, “The troops that are with you are too many for me to give Midian into their hands; Israel will boast, saying, ‘My hand has delivered me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, please proclaim in the hearing of the troops, saying, ‘Whoever is fearful and trembling, let him return and depart from the Mount of Gilead.’” About twenty-two thousand troops returned, and ten thousand remained.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said to Gideon, “There are still too many troops; bring them down to the water, and I will sift through them for you there. For whomever I say to you, ‘This one will go with you,’ he will go with you; and for all whom I say to you, ‘This one will not go with you,’ he will not go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought down the troops to the water, and Yahweh said to Gideon, “You must separate everyone who laps up the water to drink with his tongue like a dog from those who kneel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The number of those lapping up the water with their hand to their mouth was three hundred men; all the rest of the troops kneeled to drink the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said to Gideon, “I will deliver you with the three hundred men lapping up the water; I will give Midian into your hand, so let the other troops go, each to his own place.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took their provisions and their trumpets into their hand, and he sent all the men of Israel, each one, to his tent; but three hundred of the men he kept; the camp of Midian was below him in the valley.
speaker: Narrator

text: And that night Yahweh said to him, “Get up; go down against the camp, for I have given it into your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you are afraid, go down to the camp with Purah your servant,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you will hear what they say; and afterward you will have courage, and you will go down against the camp.” Then he went down with Purah his servant to the outpost of the armed men that were in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Midianites, Amalekites, and all the people of the east were lying in the valley, like a great multitude of locusts; their camels were without number, as numerous as the sand that is on the shore of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon came, a man was recounting a dream to his friend, and he said, “Behold, I had a dream; a round loaf of barley bread was tumbling into the camp of Midian, and it came up to the tent, it struck it, and it fell and turned it upside down so that the tent fell.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His friend answered him and said, “This cannot be anything except the sword of Gideon son of Jehoash, a man of Israel; God has given Midian and the entire camp into his hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gideon heard the recounting of the dream and its interpretation, he bowed down and returned to the camp of Israel; and he said, “Get up, for Yahweh has given the camp of Midian into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He divided the three hundred men into three companies, and he put trumpets and empty jars in everyone’s hand, with torches inside the jars.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to them, “Watch me and do the same. When I come to the edge of the camp, do just as I do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I and all who are with me blow on the trumpet, you must also blow on the trumpets and surround the camp, and you must say, ‘To Yahweh and to Gideon!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gideon and the hundred men who were with him came to the edge of the camp at the beginning of the middle night-watch, when they had just finished setting up the guards, and they blew on the trumpets and smashed the jars that were in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: When three companies blew on the trumpets and broke the jars, they held in their left hand the torches and in their right hand the trumpets for blowing, and they cried, “A sword for Yahweh and for Gideon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And each stood in his place all around the camp, and all the camp ran, and they cried out as they fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they blew the three hundred trumpets, Yahweh set the sword of each one against his neighbor throughout the whole camp, and the camp fled as far as Beth Shittah toward Zererah, up to Abel Meholah, the border by Tabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Israel were called from Naphtali, from Asher, and from all of Manasseh, and they pursued after Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon sent messengers throughout all the hill country of Ephraim, saying, “Come down to oppose Midian, and capture from them the waters up to Beth Barah and the Jordan.” He called out all the men of Ephraim, and they captured the waters up to Beth Barah and the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they captured the two commanders of Midian, Oreb and Zeeb, and they killed Oreb at the rock of Oreb, and they killed Zeeb at the wine press of Zeeb, while they chased Midian; and they brought the heads of Oreb and Zeeb to Gideon from beyond the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Ephraim said to him, “What is this thing you have done to us, not calling us when you went to fight against the Midianites?” And they quarreled with him severely.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to them, “What I have done now in comparison with you? Are not the gleanings of Ephraim better than the grape harvest of Abiezer?
speaker: Narrator

text: God has given into your hand the commanders of Midian, Oreb, and Zeeb. What have I been able to do in comparison with you?” And their anger against him subsided when he said that.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon came to the Jordan, crossing it with the three hundred men who were with him, weary and pursuing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the men of Succoth, “Please give loaves of bread to the people who are following me, for they are weary, and I am pursuing Zebah and Zalmunna, the kings of Midian.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials of Succoth said, “Is the hand of Zebah and Zalmunna in your hand now, that we should give bread to your army?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon said, “Well then, when Yahweh gives Zebah and Zalmunna into my hand, I will trample your flesh with the thorns and briers of the wilderness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He went from there to Penuel, and he spoke similarly to them; and the men of Penuel answered him just as the men of Succoth answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said also to the men of Penuel, saying, “When I return safely, I will tear down this tower.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zebah and Zalmunna were in Karkor, and their armies with them, about fifteen thousand men remained from the entire army of the people of the east; those that fell in battle were one hundred and twenty thousand swordsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon went up the route of those who dwell in tents on the east of Nobah and Jogbehah, and he attacked the army when it was off its guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Zebah and Zalmunna fled, and he pursued them and captured the two kings of Midian, Zebah and Zalmunna, and he routed the entire army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gideon son of Jehoash returned from the battle by way of the ascent of Heres.
speaker: Narrator

text: He captured a young man from Succoth and questioned him. The young man listed for him the commanders of Succoth and its elders, seventy-seven men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came to the men of Succoth, and he said, “Here is Zebah and Zalmunna, about whom you taunted me, saying, ‘Is the palm of Zebah and Zalmunna in your hand now, that we should give food to your weary men?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the elders of the city and the thorn bushes and briers of the wilderness, and he trampled the men of Succoth with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He broke down the tower of Penuel, and he killed the men of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to Zebah and Zalmunna, “What type were the men whom you killed at Tabor?” And they said, “They were like you; each one of them had the appearance of the sons of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “They were my brothers, the sons of my mother. As Yahweh lives, if you had kept them alive I would not kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to Jether, his firstborn, “Get up, kill them.” But the boy did not draw his sword, for he was afraid because he was still a boy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebah and Zalmunna said, “Get up yourself, and strike us, for as is the man, so is his power.” So Gideon got up and killed Zebah and Zalmunna, and he took the crescent ornaments that were on the necks of their camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel said to Gideon, “Rule over us, both you and your sons, and your sons’ son, for you have delivered us from the hand of Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Gideon said to them, “I will not rule over you, and my son will not rule over you; Yahweh will rule over you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon said to them, “Let me make a request of you, that each of you give to me an ornamental ring from his plunder.” (They had ornamental rings of gold, because they were Ishmaelites.)
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “We will gladly give them,” and they spread out a garment, and everyone threw there an ornamental ring of his plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: The weight of the ornamental rings of gold that he requested was one thousand seven hundred shekels of gold, apart from the crescents, pendants, and purple garments that were on the kings of Midian, and apart from the pendants that were on the necks of their camels.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gideon made an ephod out of it, and he put it in his town in Ophrah, and all Israel prostituted themselves to it there, and it became a snare to Gideon and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Midian was subdued before the Israelites, and they did not again lift up their head, and the land rested for forty years in the days of Gideon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerub-Baal son of Joash lived in his own house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Gideon had seventy sons, his own offspring, for he had many wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: His concubine who was in Shechem also bore for him a son, and he named him Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gideon son of Joash died at a good old age, and he was buried in the tomb of Jehoash his father, in Ophrah of the Abiezrites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it happened, as soon as Gideon died, the Israelites returned and prostituted themselves after the Baals, and they made for themselves Baal-Berith as god.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did not remember Yahweh their God, who had delivered them from the hand of their enemies from all around,
speaker: Narrator

text: nor did they show favor to the house of Jerub-Baal (that is, Gideon) in accordance with all the good that he did for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelech son of Jerub-Baal went to Shechem, to the relatives of his mother, and he said to them and to the house of his mother’s father,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the lords of Shechem, ‘What is better for you, that seventy men all from the sons of Jerub-Baal rule over you, or that one man rules over you?’ Remember that I am your bone and your flesh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And his mother’s relatives spoke all these words concerning him to all the lords of Shechem; and they supported Abimelech, for they said, “He is our relative.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they gave to him seventy pieces of silver from the temple of Baal-Berith, and Abimelech hired with them worthless and reckless men, and they followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he went to his father’s house at Ophrah, and he killed his brothers, the sons of Jerub-Baal, seventy men, on one stone. But Jotham the youngest son of Jerub-Baal survived, because he hid himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the lords of Shechem and Beth-Millo gathered, and they went and made Abimelech as king, near the oak of the pillar that is at Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they told Jotham, and he went up and stood on the top of Mount Gerizim, and he cried out loud and said to them, “Listen to me, lords of Shechem, so that God may listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The trees went certainly,
    to anoint a king over themselves.
And they said to the olive tree,
    ‘Rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the olive tree replied,
    ‘Should I stop producing my oil,
        which by me gods and men are honored,
        to go sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the trees said to the fig tree,
    ‘You, come rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the fig tree said to them,
    ‘Should I stop producing my sweetness,
        and my good crop,
        to go sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the trees said to the vine,
    ‘You, come rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the vine said to them,
    ‘Should I stop producing my wine
    that makes the gods and men happy,
        to go sway over the trees?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So all the trees said to the thornbush,
    ‘You, come rule over us.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the thornbush said to the trees,
    ‘If in good faith you are anointing
    me as king over you,
        then come and take refuge in my shade;
    if not, may fire go out from the thornbush
        and devour the cedars of Lebanon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So then, if you have acted in good faith and sincerity in making Abimelech king, and if you have dealt well with Jerub-Baal and his house, and have dealt with him according to his accomplishments—
speaker: Narrator

text: for my father fought and risked his life for you and delivered you from the hand of Midian;
speaker: Narrator

text: but today you have risen against the house of my father and killed his sons, seventy men on one stone, and you have made Abimelech, the son of his slave woman, a king over the lords of Shechem, because he is your relative—
speaker: Narrator

text: if you have acted in good faith and sincerity with Jerub-Baal and his house this day, then rejoice in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if not, let a fire come out from Abimelech and let it devour the lords of Shechem and Beth-Millo; and let a fire come out from the lords of Shechem, and from Beth-Millo, and let it devour Abimelech.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jotham escaped and fled, and went to Beer; he remained there because of Abimelech his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech ruled over Israel three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the lords of Shechem, and the lords of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelech,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the violence done to the seventy brothers of Abimelech would be avenged and their blood be placed on Abimelech their brother, who killed them, and on the lords of Shechem, who helped to kill his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the lords of Shechem set for him ambushes on the top of the mountains, and they robbed all who passed by them along the road; and it was reported to Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gaal son of Ebel and his relatives came, and they crossed over into Shechem, and the lords of Shechem gave him confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out into the field and harvested their vineyards and trod them, and they held a festival. And they went into the temple of their god, and they ate and drank and cursed Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gaal son of Ebed said, “Who is Abimelech, and who are we of Shechem that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerub-Baal, and is not Zebul his chief officer? Serve the men of Hamor the father of Shechem. Why should we serve him?
speaker: Narrator

text: If only this people were in my command! Then I would remove Abimelech, and I would have said, ‘Increase your army and come out!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zebul the commander of the city heard the words of Gaal son of Ebed, he became angry,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he sent messengers to Abimelech in Tormah, saying, “Look, Gaal son of Ebed and his relatives are coming to Shechem, and they are stirring up the city against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, get up by night, you and the army that is with you, and lie in ambush in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the morning at sunrise, get up and rush the city; and look, when he and the troops who are with him come out to you, you must act according to whatever opportunity offers itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech and all the army that was with him got up by night, and they lay in ambush against Shechem in four divisions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gaal son of Ebed went out and stood at the entrance of the city gate, and Abimelech and the army that was with him got up from the ambush.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Gaal saw the army, he said to Zebul, “Look, people are coming down from the top of the mountains!” And Zebul said to him, “The shadows of the mountains look like people to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Gaal spoke again and said, “Look, people are coming down from Tabbur-erez, and one division is coming from the direction of Elon-meonenim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Zebul said to him, “Where then is your boast, you who said, ‘Who is Abimelech that we should serve him?’ Is this not the army that you rejected? Please, go out now and fight against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gaal went out before the lords of Shechem and fought against Abimelech.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Abimelech chased him, and he fled before him; many fell slain up to the entrance of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech resided at Arumah, and Zebul drove out Gaal and his relatives from living in Shechem.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day the people went out to the field; and it was reported to Abimelech,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he took the army and divided them into three divisions, and he laid an ambush in the field. And he saw the people were coming out from the city, and he arose against them and killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech and the divisions that were with him dashed out and stood at the entrance of the city gate, and the two divisions dashed out against all who were in the field, and they killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech fought against the city all that day, and he captured the city and killed the people that were in it; then he broke down the city and sowed it with salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the lords of the tower of Shechem heard, they went to the vault of the temple of El-Berith.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was told to Abimelech that all the lords of the tower of Shechem had gathered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abimelech went up Mount Zalmon, he and all his army that were with him, and Abimelech took the ax in his hand and cut down a bundle of brushwood, and he lifted it and put it on his shoulder. And he said to the army that was with him, “What you have seen me do, quickly do also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the whole army cut down each one branch for himself and followed Abimelech, and they put them against the vault and set the vault ablaze with fire on those inside, so that all the men of the tower of Shechem died, about a thousand men and women.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abimelech went to Thebez, and he encamped against Thebez and captured it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there was a strong tower in the middle of the city, and all the men, women, and lords of the city fled there and shut themselves in; and they went up to the roof of the tower.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abimelech came up to the tower and fought against it, and he came near the entrance of the tower to burn it with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a certain woman threw an upper millstone on Abimelech’s head and cracked open his skull.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called quickly to the young man carrying his weapons, and he said to him, “Draw your sword and kill me, so that they will not say of me, ‘A woman killed him.’” So the young man stabbed him, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of Israel saw that Abimelech was dead, each one went to his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: So God repaid the wickedness that Abimelech committed against his father by killing his seventy brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God also repaid all the wickedness of the men of Shechem on their heads, and the curse of Jotham son of Jerub-Baal fell on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Abimelech, Tola son of Puah son of Dod, a man of Issachar, rose up to deliver Israel; and he was living at Shamir in the hill country of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he judged Israel twenty-three years. And he died and was buried in Shamir.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Jair the Gileadite rose up, and he judged Israel twenty-two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he had thirty sons who would ride on thirty donkeys, and they had thirty towns that are in the land of Gilead that they called Havvoth Jair until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jair died and was buried in Kamon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And again, the Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh. They served the Baals, the Ashtaroth, the gods of Aram, Sidon, Moab, and the gods of the Ammonites and Philistines; they abandoned Yahweh and did not serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the anger of Yahweh burned against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of the Philistines and the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They crushed and oppressed the Israelites in that year; for eighteen years they crushed all the Israelites who were beyond the Jordan, in the land of the Amorites, which is in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites crossed the Jordan to fight also against Judah, Benjamin, and the house of Ephraim; and Israel was very distressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites cried out to Yahweh, saying, “We have sinned against you; we have abandoned our God and served the Baals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh said to the Israelites, “Did I not deliver you from the Egyptians, the Amorites, from the Ammonites, and from the Philistines?
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the Sidonians, the Amalekites, and the Maonites oppressed you, you cried out to me, and I delivered you from their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet you have abandoned me and served other gods. Therefore I will no longer deliver you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and cry out to the gods whom you have chosen; let them deliver you in the time of your trouble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites said to Yahweh, “We have sinned; do to us accordingly as you see fit; only please deliver us this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they removed the foreign gods from their midst and served Yahweh; and he could no longer bear the misery of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Ammonites were summoned, and they camped in Gilead. And the Israelites gathered and camped at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people, the ones commanding Gilead, said to each other, “Who is the man that will begin to fight against the Ammonites? He will be as head over all the inhabitants of Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty warrior; he was the son of a prostitute, and Gilead was his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gilead’s wife also bore for him sons; and the sons of his wife grew up and drove Jephthah away, and they said to him, “You will not inherit the house of our father because you are the son of another woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah fled from the presence of his brothers, and he lived in the land of Tob. And outlaws gathered around Jephthah and went with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a time the Ammonites made war with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites made war with Israel, the elders of Gilead went to bring Jephthah from the land of Tob.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to Jephthah, “Come and be our commander, so that we may make war against the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah said to the elders, “Did you not shun me and drive me out from the house of my father? Why do you come to me now when you have trouble?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, “That being so, we have now returned to you, that you may go with us to fight against the Ammonites and become for us as head of all the inhabitants of Gilead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah said to the elders of Gilead, “If you bring me back to fight against the Ammonites, and Yahweh gives them over to me, will I be your head?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the elders of Gilead said to Jephthah, “Yahweh will be a witness between us; we will act according to your word.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him head and commander over them. And Jephthah spoke all his words before Yahweh at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites, saying, “What is between you and me that you have come to me to make war against my land?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of the Ammonites said to Jephthah’s messengers, “Because Israel took my land from the Arnon up to the Jabbok and the Jordan when they came up from Egypt; so then, restore it peacefully.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again Jephthah sent messengers to the king of the Ammonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to him, “Thus says Jephthah, ‘Israel did not take the land of Moab or the land of the Ammonites,
speaker: Narrator

text: because when they came up from Egypt, Israel went through the wilderness to the Red Sea and went to Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, “Please let us cross through your land,” but the king of Edom would not listen. And they also sent messengers to the king of Moab, but he was not willing. So Israel stayed in Kadesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they traveled through the wilderness, went around the land of Edom and Moab, and came to the east side of the land of Moab, and they encamped beyond the Arnon; and they did not go into the territory of Moab because the Arnon was the border of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel sent messengers to Sihon king of the Amorites, king of Heshbon; and Israel said to him, ‘Please let us cross through your land to our country.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon did not trust Israel to cross through his territory, so Sihon gathered all his people and then encamped at Jahaz; and he made war with Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh, the God of Israel, gave Sihon and all his people into the hand of Israel, and they defeated them; and Israel occupied all the land of the Amorites inhabiting that land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They occupied all the territory of the Amorites from the Arnon up to the Jabbok, and from the wilderness up to the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then Yahweh, the God of Israel, has driven out the Amorites from before his people Israel, and you want to possess it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do you not possess what Chemosh your god gave you to possess? Whoever Yahweh our God has driven out before us, we will possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, are you any better than Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab? Did he ever quarrel with Israel, or did he ever make war against them?
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel lived in Heshbon and its villages, and in Aroer and its villages, and in all the towns that are along the Arnon, for three hundred years, why did you not recover them at that time?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not sinned against you; but you are the one who is doing wrong by making war against me. Let Yahweh judge today between the Israelites and the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of the Ammonites did not listen to the message that Jephthah sent to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Spirit of Yahweh came upon Jephthah, and he passed through Gilead and Manasseh. He passed through Mizpah of Gilead, and from Mizpah of Gilead he passed through to the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jephthah made a vow to Yahweh, and he said, “If indeed you will give the Ammonites into my hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: whatever comes out from the doors of my house to meet me when I return safely from the Ammonites will be Yahweh’s, and I will offer it as a burnt offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jephthah crossed over to the Ammonites to make war against them; and Yahweh gave them into his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he defeated them with a very great blow, from Aroer as far as Minnith, twenty towns, up to Abel Keramim. And the Ammonites were subdued before the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah came to Mizpah, to his house, and behold his daughter came out to meet him with tambourines and dancing. She was his only child; he did not have a son or daughter except her.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the moment he saw her, he tore his clothes and said, “Ah! My daughter, you have caused me to bow down, and you have become my trouble. I made an oath to Yahweh, and I cannot take it back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “My father, you made an oath to Yahweh. Do to me according to what has gone out from your mouth, since Yahweh gave vengeance to you against your enemies, the Ammonites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to her father, “Let this thing be done for me: grant me two months so that I may go wander on the mountains and lament over my virginity, I and my companions.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said, “Go.” He sent her away for two months, and she went with her friends, and she lamented over her virginity on the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of the two months she returned to her father, and he did to her according to his vow; and she did not sleep with a man. And it became an annual custom in Israel
speaker: Narrator

text: for the daughters of Israel to go and lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite for forty days of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Ephraim were called to arms, and they crossed over to Zaphon and said to Jephthah, “Why did you cross over and make war against the Ammonites, and why did you not call us to go with you? We will burn down your house over you with fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jephthah said to them, “I and my people were engaged in great conflict with the Ammonites; I called you, but you did not deliver me from their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw that you would not deliver us; I risked my own life, and I crossed over to the Ammonites, and Yahweh gave them into my hand. Why have you come up to me this day to fight against me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah gathered all the men of Gilead, and he made war with Ephraim; and the men of Gilead defeated Ephraim because they said, “You are fugitives of Ephraim, you Gileadites, in the midst of Ephraim and Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Gilead captured the fords of the Jordan from Ephraim, and whenever a fugitive of Ephraim said, “Let me cross over,” the men of Gilead said to him, “Are you an Ephraimite?” When he said, “No,”
speaker: Narrator

text: they said to him, “Please say Shibboleth,” and if he said, “Sibboleth”—because he could not pronounce it correctly—they grabbed him and executed him at the fords of Jordan. At that time forty-two thousand from Ephraim fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jephthah judged Israel six years. Then Jephthah the Gileadite died, and he was buried in one of the cities of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Ibzan from Bethlehem judged Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had thirty sons. He gave his thirty daughters away in marriage outside his clan and brought in from outside thirty young women for his sons. He judged Israel for seven years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ibzan died and was buried in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Elon the Zebulunite judged Israel, and he judged Israel ten years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elon the Zebulunite died and was buried in Aijalon in the land of Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite judged Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had forty sons and thirty grandsons that rode on seventy male donkeys. He judged Israel for eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite died and was buried in Pirathon, in the land of Ephraim in the hill country of the Amalekites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And again, the Israelites did evil in the eyes of Yahweh, and Yahweh gave them into the hand of the Philistines forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a certain man from Zorah, from the tribe of the Danites, and his name was Manoah; his wife was infertile and did not bear children.
speaker: Narrator

text: And an angel of Yahweh appeared to the woman, and he said to her, “Behold, you are infertile and have not borne children, but you will conceive and bear a son.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, be careful and do not drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you will conceive and bear a son. No razor will touch his head, because the boy will be a Nazirite of God from birth. And it is he who will begin to deliver Israel from the hand of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the woman came and told her husband, saying, “A man of God came to me, and his appearance was like the appearance of an angel of God, very awesome. I did not ask him from where he came, and he did not tell me his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to me, ‘Look, you will conceive and bear a son, so then, do not drink wine or strong drink, and do not eat anything unclean, for the boy will be a Nazirite of God from birth until the day of his death.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Manoah prayed to Yahweh and said, “Excuse me, my Lord, please let the man of God whom you sent again come to us and teach us what we should do concerning the boy who will be born.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And God listened to the voice of Manoah, and an angel of God came again to the woman; she was sitting in the field, but Manoah her husband was not with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman quickly ran and told her husband, and she said to him, “Look! The man who came to me the other day appeared to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Manoah got up and went after his wife, and he came to the man and said to him, “Are you the man that spoke to the woman?” And he said, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manoah said to him, “Now when your words come true, what will be the boy’s manner of life and work?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the angel of Yahweh said to Manoah, “Let the woman be attentive to all that I said.
speaker: Narrator

text: She should not eat of anything that comes from the vine, or drink wine or strong drink, or eat anything unclean; she should keep all that I commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manoah said to the angel of Yahweh, “Please stay, and let us prepare a young goat for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of Yahweh said to Manoah, “If you keep me, I will not eat your food, but if you prepare a burnt offering for Yahweh, you can offer it (for Manoah did not know that he was an angel of Yahweh).”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manoah said to the angel of Yahweh, “What is your name so that when your words come true we may honor you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of Yahweh said to him, “Why do you ask my name? It is too wonderful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manoah took the young goat and the grain offering, and he offered it to Yahweh on the rock, to the one who performs miracles. And Manoah and his wife were watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the flame went up toward the heaven from the altar, the angel of Yahweh went up in the flame of the altar to heaven while Manoah and his wife were watching. And they fell on their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of Yahweh did not appear again to Manoah and his wife, and then Manoah knew that he was a messenger of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Manoah said to his wife, “We will certainly die because we have seen God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his wife said to him, “If Yahweh wanted to kill us he would not have taken from our hand the burnt offering and the grain offering, or shown us all these things, or now announced to us things such as these.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman bore a son, and she called him Samson; the boy grew big, and Yahweh blessed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Spirit of Yahweh began to stir him in the camp of Dan, between Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson went down to Timnah, and he saw a woman in Timnah from the daughters of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up and told his father and mother, and he said, “I saw a woman in Timnah from the daughters of the Philistines; so then, take her for me as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his father and mother said to him, “Is there not a wife among the daughters of your relatives, or among all our people, that you must take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?” But Samson said to his father, “Take her for me because she pleases me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: His father and mother did not know that this was from Yahweh; he was seeking for an occasion against the Philistines. Now at that time the Philistines were ruling in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson and his father and mother went down to Timnah, and they came to the vineyards of Timnah, and suddenly a young lion came roaring to meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Spirit of Yahweh rushed upon him, and he tore the lion apart as one might tear apart a male kid goat (he was bare-handed). But he did not tell his father and mother what he had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went down and talked to the woman, and she pleased Samson.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he returned after awhile to marry her, and he turned aside to see the carcass of the lion, and there was a swarm of wild honey bees in the body of the lion, and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: He scraped it out into his hands, and he went on, eating it as he went. And he went to his father and mother and gave some to them, and they ate it. But he did not tell them that he had scraped the honey from the body of the lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father went down to the woman, and Samson prepared there a feast, as young men were accustomed to doing this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they saw him, they took thirty companions, and they were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson said to them, “Let me tell you a riddle. If you can fully explain it to me within the seven days of the feast, and find it out, I will give to you thirty linen garments and thirty festal garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you are unable to explain it to me, you must give me thirty linen garments and thirty festal garments.” So they said to him, “Tell your riddle; let us hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them,
“From the eater came out food,
    From the strong came out sweet.”
But they were unable to explain the riddle for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was the fourth day, they said to Samson’s wife, “Entice your husband and tell us the riddle, or we will burn you and your father’s house with fire. Have you invited us to rob us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson’s wife wept before him, and she said, “You must hate me; you do not love me. You told the riddle to my people, but you have not explained it to me.” He said to her, “I have not explained it to my father and mother. Why should I explain it to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She wept before him the seven days of their feast; and it happened, because she nagged him, on the seventh day he explained it to her, and she told the riddle to her people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The men of the city said to him on the seventh day before the sun went down,
“What is sweeter than honey?
    What is stronger than a lion?”
And he said to them,
“If you had not plowed with my heifer,
    you would not have found out my riddle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Spirit of Yahweh rushed on him, and he went down to Ashkelon. He killed thirty men from them, and he took their belongings, and he gave festal garments to the ones that explained the riddle. He was angry, and he went up to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson’s wife was given to his companion who was his best man.
speaker: Narrator

text: After a while, at the time of the wheat harvest, Samson visited his wife with a young goat. He said, “I want to go to my wife’s private room.” But her father would not allow him to enter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her father said, “I really thought that you hated her, so I gave her to your companion. Is not her younger sister more beautiful than she? Please, take her instead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson said to them, “This time, as far as the Philistines are concerned, when I do something evil I am without blame.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson went and captured three hundred foxes, and he took torches. He turned them tail to tail, and he put one torch between two tails.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set fire to the torches and let the foxes go into the standing grain of the Philistines, and he burned both the stacks of sheaves and the standing grain, up to the vineyards of olive groves.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Philistines said, “Who has done this?” And they said, “Samson the son-in-law of the Timnite, because he took his wife and gave her to his companion.” And the Philistines went up and burned her and her father with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to them, “If you want to behave like this, I swear I will not rest unless I have taken revenge on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he gave them a thorough beating, and he went down and stayed in the cleft of the rock of Etam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Philistines came up and encamped in Judah, and they overran Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Judah said, “Why have you come up against us?” And they said, “To bind Samson; to do to him just as he did to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then three thousand men from Judah went down to the cleft of the rock of Etam, and they said to Samson, “Do you not know that the Philistines are ruling over us? What is this that you have done to us?” And he said to them, “Just as they did to me, so I have done to them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “We have come down to bind you and give you over into the hand of the Philistines.” And Samson said to them, “Swear to me that you will not attack me yourselves.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to him, “No, we will only bind you and give you into their hand; we will certainly not kill you.” So they bound him with two new ropes, and they brought him up from the rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: As he came up to Lehi, the Philistines came shouting to meet him; and the Spirit of Yahweh rushed on him, and the ropes that were on his arms became like flax that has burned with fire, and his bindings melted from his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he found a fresh jawbone of a donkey; he reached down and took it and killed one thousand men with it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And Samson said,
“With the jawbone of the donkey,
    heap upon heap;
with the jawbone of the donkey,
    I struck dead one thousand men.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it happened, when he finished speaking he threw the jawbone from his hand; and he called that place Ramath Lehi.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he was very thirsty, and he called to Yahweh and said, “You gave this great victory into the hand of your servant, but now I must die of thirst and fall into the hand of the uncircumcised?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God split the hollow place that is at Lehi, and water came out from it; and he drank, and his spirit returned, and he was revived. Thus he called its name The Spring of Ha-Qore, which is at Lehi to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he judged Israel in the days of the Philistines twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson went down to Gaza; there he saw a prostitute and had sex with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gazites were told, “Samson has come here,” so they surrounded the place and lay in ambush for him all night at the city gate. They kept silent all night, saying, “We will wait until the morning light, and then we will kill him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Samson lay until the middle of the night; he got up in the middle of the night and took hold of the doors of the city gate and the two door posts, tore them loose with the bar, put them on his shoulders, and carried them up to the top of the hill that is in front of Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this he fell in love with a woman in the wadi of Sorek, and her name was Delilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rulers of the Philistines came up to her and said, “Entice him and find out what makes his strength so great, and how we can overpower him, so that we may bind him up in order to subdue him; each of us will give you eleven hundred pieces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah said to Samson, “Please tell me what makes your strength so great, and with what can you be tied up to subdue you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Samson said to her, “If you tie me up with seven fresh bowstrings that are not dried up, I will become weak like everyone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the rulers of the Philistines brought up to her seven fresh bowstrings that were not dried up, and she tied him up with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ambush was sitting in wait for her in an inner room. And she said to him, “The Philistines are upon you Samson!” And he snapped the bowstrings just as flax fiber snaps when it comes close to fire. And the secret of his strength remained unknown.
speaker: Narrator

text: Delilah said to Samson, “Look, you have mocked me and told me lies. Please tell me how you can be bound.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “If they tie me tightly with new ropes that have not been used, I will become weak and be like everyone else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Delilah took new ropes and tied him up with them, and she said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” (The ambush was sitting in an inner room.) But he snapped them from his arms like thread.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Delilah said to Samson, “Until now you have mocked me and told lies to me. Tell me how you can be bound.” And he said to her, “If you weave seven locks of my head with warp-threads.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She fastened it with the pin and said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” And Samson woke up from his sleep and tore loose the loom pin of the web and the warp-threads.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to him, “How can you say, ‘I love you,’ when your heart is not with me? You have mocked me these three times, and you have not told me how your strength is so great.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And because she nagged him day after day with her words, and pestered him, his soul grew impatient to the point of death.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he confided everything to her, and he said to her, “A razor has never touched my head, for I am a Nazirite of God from birth. If I am shaved my strength will leave me, and I will become weak, like everyone else.
speaker: Narrator

text: Delilah realized that he had confided in her, so she sent and called the rulers of the Philistines, saying, “Come up one more time, for he has confided in me.” And the rulers of the Philistines came up, and they brought the money with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she put him to sleep on her lap; then she called the men and shaved off seven locks of his head. Then she began to subdue him, and his strength went away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And she said to him, “The Philistines are upon you, Samson!” And he woke up from his sleep and said, “I will go out just like every other time and shake myself free,” but he did not know that Yahweh had left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Philistines seized him, gouged his eyes, and brought him to Gaza. They tied him up with bronze shackles, and he became a grinder in the prison.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the hair of his head began to grow back after it had been shaved off.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rulers of the Philistines had gathered to sacrifice a great sacrifice to Dagon their god and to rejoice. And they said, “Our god has given Samson our enemy into our hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people saw him, and they praised their god, for they said, “Our god has given into our hand those who hate us, devastate our land, and have killed many of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After awhile, when their hearts were merry, they said, “Call Samson and let him entertain us.” And they called Samson from the prison, and he entertained them. And they made him stand between the pillars.
speaker: Narrator
