text: Then Samson said to the servant who was holding him by his hand, “Position me so that I can touch the pillars on which the house rests, so I can lean on them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the house was full of men and women, and all of the rulers of the Philistines were there—about three thousand men and women were on the roof watching the performance of Samson.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson called to Yahweh and said, “My Lord Yahweh, remember me! Please give me strength this one time, O God, so that I can repay with one act of revenge to the Philistines for my eyes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson reached out and held two of the middle pillars on which the house was resting, and he leaned on them, one on his right and one on his left.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Samson said, “Let me die with the Philistines.” And he pushed with all his strength, and the house fell on the rulers and all of the people who were with him. And the dead whom he killed in his death were more than those he killed in his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: His brothers and his whole family came down and picked him up; and they brought him up and buried him between Zorah and Eshtaol in the tomb of Manoah his father; he judged Israel twenty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man from the hill country of Ephraim; his name was Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to his mother, “The eleven hundred pieces of silver that were taken from you, and about which you also pronounced a curse in my hearing, are with me; I took it.” And his mother said, “Blessed be my son by Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He returned the eleven hundred pieces of silver to his mother, and his mother thought, “I will certainly consecrate to Yahweh the pieces of silver from my hand for my son to make an idol of cast metal; now then, I will return them to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he returned the pieces of silver to his mother, his mother took two hundred pieces of silver, and she gave it to the smith, and he made it into an idol of cast metal; and it was in the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man Micah had for himself a shrine, and he made an ephod and teraphim, and he appointed one of his sons who became a priest for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days there was no king in Israel, and each one did what was right in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a young man from Bethlehem in Judah, from the clan of Judah; he was a Levite and was dwelling as a foreigner there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the man went from the town of Bethlehem in Judah to live as a foreigner wherever he could find a place. And he came to the hill country of Ephraim, to the house of Micah, to continue his journey.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Micah said to him, “From where do you come?” And he said to him, “I am a Levite from Bethlehem in Judah; I am going to dwell as a foreigner wherever I can find a place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Micah said to him, “Stay with me and be to me a father and a priest, and I will give to you ten pieces of silver a year, a set of clothes, and your food.” So the Levite went with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levite agreed to stay with the man; and the young man became as one of his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Micah appointed the Levite, and the young man became a priest for him; and he was in the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Micah said, “Now I know Yahweh will make me prosperous, because the Levite has become my priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days there was no king in Israel. And in those days the tribe of the Danites was seeking territory for itself to live in, because until that day it had not been allotted territory among the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Dan sent from the whole number of their clan five capable men from Zorah and Eshtaol to spy out the land and to explore it. And they said to them, “Go, explore the land.” And they went to the hill country of Ephraim, to the house of Micah, and they spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were with the house of Micah, they recognized the voice of the young Levite, and they turned aside there and said to him, “Who brought you here? What are you doing in this place, and what is your business here?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to them, “Micah did such and such for me and hired me, and I became his priest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to him, “Please inquire of God that we may know whether our journey that we are going on will be successful.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priest said to them, “Go in peace. Yahweh is in front of you on the journey you want to go on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the five men went and came to Laish, and they observed the people who were living according to the customs of the Sidonians, quiet and unsuspecting, and lacking nothing in the land, and possessing restraint. And they were far from the Sidonians and had no word with anyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came to their relatives at Zorah and Eshtaol, and their relatives said to them, “What do you report?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to them, “Come, let us go up against them; for we have seen the land, and it is very good. Will you do nothing? Do not hesitate to go, to enter, to possess the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go you will come to an unsuspecting people, and the land is spread out on all sides; God has given a place into your hands where there is no lack of anything that is on the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Six hundred men from the clan of the Danites from Zorah and Eshtaol, armed with weapons of war, set out from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went up and encamped at Kiriath Jearim in Judah. Therefore they called this place Camp of Dan to this day; it is west of Kiriath Jearim.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they crossed over to the hill country of Ephraim, and they came to the house of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the five men that went out to spy out the land (that is, Laish) responded and said to their relatives, “Do you know that there are in these houses an ephod, teraphim, and an idol of cast metal? So then, consider what you must do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they turned to that direction, and they came to the house of the young Levite, the house of Micah, and they greeted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And six hundred men from the descendants of Dan, armed with their weapons of war, were standing at the entrance of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the five men that went to spy out the land went up, and they entered there and took the carved divine image, ephod, teraphim, and the molten image. The priest was standing at the entrance of the gate with the six hundred men armed with the weapons of war.
speaker: Narrator

text: When these went to Micah’s house, they took the divine carved image, ephod, the teraphim, and the molten image, and the priest asked them, “What are you doing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said to him, “Keep quiet! Put your hand on your mouth and come with us and be for us a father and a priest. Is it better being a priest for a house of one man or being a priest for a tribe and clan in Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest accepted the offer, and he took the ephod, teraphim, and molten image and went along with the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they turned and went and put the little children, the livestock, and the valuable property in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were at a distance from the house, Micah and the men who were in the houses that were near the house of Micah cried out, and they overtook the descendants of Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they called to the descendants of Dan, who turned around to face them, and they said to Micah, “What is the matter with you that you assembled together?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You took away my gods that I had made, and the priest, and then you go away. What is now left for me? How can you say to me, ‘What is the matter?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the descendants of Dan said to him, “You should not let your voice be heard among us, so that ill-tempered men will not attack you, and take your life and the lives of your household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the descendants of Dan went their way. When Micah saw that they were stronger than him, he turned to return to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they took what Micah had made, and his priest, and they came to Laish, to a quiet and unsuspecting people, and they put them to the sword and burned the city with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no deliverer, because it was far from Sidon, and they had had no dealings with anyone. It was in the valley that belonged to Beth-rehob, and they rebuilt the city and lived in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they called the name of the city Dan, after Dan their ancestor, who was born to Israel; but the former name of the city was Laish.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the descendants of Dan set up for themselves the carved divine image, and Jonathan son of Gershom, son of Manasseh, he and his sons were priests for the tribe of the Danites until the time of the captivity of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they set up for themselves the carved divine image that Micah had made, all the days that the house of God was in Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days there was no king in Israel; there was a man, a Levite, who dwelled as a foreigner in the remote areas of the hill country of Ephraim. And he took for himself a concubine from Bethlehem in Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his concubine felt repugnance toward him, and she left him and went to her father’s house, to Bethlehem in Judah; she was there some four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: So her husband set out, and he went after her to speak tenderly to her, to bring her back. He took with him his servant and a pair of donkeys. And she brought him to her father’s house, and the father of the young woman saw him and was glad to meet him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father-in-law, the young woman’s father, urged him to stay with him three days; and they ate and drank, and they spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day, they rose early in the morning, and he prepared to go, but the father of the young woman said to his son-in-law, “Refresh yourself with a bit of food, and afterward you may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the two of them sat and ate and drank together, and the father of the young woman said to the man, “Please, agree to spend the night and enjoy yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man got up to go, but his father-in-law urged him, and he returned and spent the night there.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fifth day he rose early in the morning to go, and the father of the young woman said, “Please, enjoy yourself,” and they lingered until the day declined, and the two of them ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the man got up to go—he, his concubine, and his servant—but his father-in-law, the father of the young woman, said to him, “Please, the day has worn on to evening; please, spend the night, the day has drawn to a close. Spend the night here and enjoy yourself. You can rise early tomorrow for your journey and go to your home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man was not willing to spend the night, and he got up and went; and he arrived opposite Jebus (that is, Jerusalem). He had with him a pair of saddled donkeys and his concubine.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were near Jebus, and the day was far spent, and the servant said to his master, “Please, come, let us turn aside to this city of the Jebusites, and let us spend the night in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But his master said to him, “We will not turn aside to the city of foreigners, who are not from the Israelites; we will cross over up to Gibeah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to his servant, “Come, let us approach one of these places; we will spend the night in Gibeah or in Ramah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they crossed over and went their way, and the sun went down on them beside Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they turned aside there to enter and to spend the night at Gibeah. And they went and sat in the open square of the city, but no one took them in to spend the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then behold, an old man was coming from his work from the field in the evening, and the man was from the hill country of Ephraim, and he was dwelling as a foreigner in Gibeah. (The people of the place were descendants of Benjamin.)
speaker: Narrator

text: And the old man raised his eyes and saw the traveler in the open square of the city, and he said, “Where are you going, and from where do you come?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to him, “We are crossing over from Bethlehem in Judah up to the remote areas of the hill country of Ephraim, where I am from. I went to Bethlehem in Judah, but now I am going to Yahweh’s house, but no one took me in to spend the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is both straw and fodder for our donkeys, and also bread and wine for me, for your servant, and for the young man who is with your servant; there is no lack of anything.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the old man said, “Peace to you. I will take care of your needs; however, you must not spend the night in the open square.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he brought him to his house, and he fed the donkeys; they washed their feet, ate, and drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were enjoying themselves, behold, the men of the city, the perverse lot, surrounded the house, pounding on the door. And they said to the old man, the owner of the house, “Bring out the man who came to your house so that we may have sex with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man, the owner of the house, went out to them and said to them, “No, my brothers, do not act wickedly; since this man has come into my house, do not do this disgraceful thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is my virgin daughter and his concubine. Please, let me bring them out; do violence to them, and do to them whatever you please. Do not do this disgraceful thing to this man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men were not willing to listen to him, and the man seized his concubine and brought her out to them; and they had intercourse with her, and they abused her all night until the morning; they let her go at the approach of dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the woman came as the morning appeared, and she fell at the entrance of the man’s house where her master was, until daylight.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning her master got up, and he opened the doors of the house and went out to go on his journey, and behold, his concubine was falling at the entrance of the house, with her hand on the threshold.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to her, “Get up, let us go,” but there was no answer. So he put her on the donkey, and the man got up and went to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he entered his house he took a knife, and he grasped his concubine and cut her into twelve pieces; and he sent her throughout the whole territory of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who saw it said, “Nothing like this has ever been since the Israelites went up from the land of Egypt until this day. Take note of it, consider it, and speak up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites went out, from Dan to Beersheba, including the land of Gilead, and they gathered as one body to Yahweh at Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the leaders of all the people, all the tribes of Israel, presented themselves in the assembly of the people of God, four hundred thousand sword-bearing infantry.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The descendants of Benjamin heard that the Israelites had gone up to Mizpah.) And the Israelites said, “Tell us, how did this evil act occur?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levite, the husband of the murdered woman, answered and said, “I came to Gibeah, which belongs to Benjamin, I and my concubine, to spend the night.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lords of Gibeah rose up against me and surrounded the house at night. They intended to kill me, and they raped my concubine, and she died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I grabbed my concubine and cut her into pieces, and I sent her throughout all the territory of Israel’s inheritance; for they committed a shameful and disgraceful thing in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, all you Israelites! Make your decision and advice here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people got up as one body, saying, “Not one of us will go to his tent, or will any of us return to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, this is what we will do to Gibeah: we will go up against her by lot.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will take ten men of one hundred from all the tribes of Israel, and one hundred of one thousand, and one thousand of ten thousand, to bring provisions to the troops, to repay them when they come to Gibeah of Benjamin for all the disgraceful things they did in Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the men of Israel were gathered to the city as one body united.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the tribes of Israel sent men throughout all the tribes of Benjamin, saying, “What is this wickedness that happened among you?
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, hand over the men, the perverse lot, who are in Gibeah, so that we may kill them and purge this wickedness from Israel.” But the descendants of Benjamin were not willing to listen to the voice of their relatives, the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the descendants of Benjamin were gathered from the cities to Gibeah to go out for battle against the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the cities the descendants of Benjamin were counted on that day twenty-six thousand sword-wielding men, besides the inhabitants of Gibeah, who were counted seven hundred well-trained men.
speaker: Narrator

text: From all these troops were seven hundred well-trained men who were left-handed; each one could sling with a stone at a hair and not miss.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Israel besides Benjamin were counted four hundred thousand sword-wielding men; all were warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites got up and went up to Bethel, and they inquired of God, saying, “Who will go up first for the battle against the descendants of Benjamin?” And Yahweh said, “Judah will go first.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites got up in the morning, and they encamped against Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Israel marched out for the battle against Benjamin, and the men of Israel took up positions against them for battle at Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Benjamin went out from Gibeah, and they struck down on that day twenty-two thousand men of Israel to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the troops, the men of Israel, encouraged themselves, and again they arranged their battle lines in the place where they had arranged themselves the first day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites went up and wept before Yahweh until evening and inquired of Yahweh, saying, “Should we again draw near from the battle against the descendants of Benjamin, our relatives?” And Yahweh said, “Go up against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites drew near to the descendants of Benjamin on the second day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Benjamin went out from Gibeah to meet them on the second day, and they struck down the Israelites again, eighteen thousand men to the ground; all of these were sword-wielding.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the Israelites and all the troops went up and came to Bethel and wept; and they sat there before Yahweh and fasted on that day until evening; and they offered burnt offerings and fellowship offerings before Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites inquired of Yahweh (In those days the ark of the covenant of God was there,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Phinehas son of Eleazar, son of Aaron, was standing before it to minister in those days), saying, “Should we go out once more to battle against the descendants of Benjamin our relatives, or should we stop?” And Yahweh said, “Go up tomorrow; I will give them into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel stationed an ambush all around Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites went up against the descendants of Benjamin on the third day, and they took up positions against Gibeah as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Benjamin went out to meet the troops, and they lured them away from the city and began to inflict casualties on the troops as before, on the main road, one of which goes up to Bethel, the other to Gibeah; and in the field there were about thirty men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the descendants of Benjamin thought, “They are being defeated before us as previously,” and the Israelites said, “Let us flee and lure them away from the city to the main roads.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the men of Israel got up from their places and took up positions in Baal Tamar; and the ambush of Israel charged from their places, from the vicinity of Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then ten thousand well-trained men from all Israel came out against Gibeah, and the battle became fierce; they did not know that disaster was about to close in on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Yahweh defeated Benjamin in the presence of Israel, and the Israelites destroyed on that day twenty-five thousand one hundred men of Benjamin, all of them sword-wielding.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Benjamin saw that they were defeated, and the men of Israel gave ground to Benjamin because they trusted the ambush that they had set against Gibeah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the ambush came quickly and advanced against Gibeah, and it put the whole city to the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the appointed time for the men of Israel with the ambush was that they sent up for them a great amount of smoke from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Israel turned in the battle, and Benjamin began to inflict casualties on about thirty men of Israel because they thought, “They will be completely defeated before us as in the first battle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the cloud of smoke began to go up from the city in a column of smoke, and Benjamin turned backward, and behold, the whole city was going up in smoke!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Israel turned, and the men of Benjamin were dismayed because they saw that disaster was closing in on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they retreated from before the men of Israel to the way of the wilderness, but the battle caught up to them, and those who came from the cities destroyed them in the midst of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They surrounded Benjamin; they pursued them without rest and trod them down opposite Gibeah to the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: And eighteen thousand men from Benjamin fell, all of them able men.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they turned and fled toward the wilderness, to the rock of Rimmon, but they cut down on the main roads five thousand men; and they pursued after them up to Gidom, and they struck down two thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all of Benjamin who fell on that day were twenty-five thousand sword-wielding men; all of these were able men.
speaker: Narrator

text: But six hundred turned and fled toward the wilderness, to the rock of Rimmon, and they remained at the rock of Rimmon for four months.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the men of Israel returned to the descendants of Benjamin, and they put them to the edge of the sword, both the inhabitants of city and the animals that were found; they also set on fire all the cities that they found.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Israel had sworn at Mizpah, saying, “None of us will give his daughter to Benjamin as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people of Bethel came and sat there until evening before God, and they lifted their voices and wept bitterly.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “Why, Yahweh, God of Israel, has it happened today in Israel that one tribe is lacking from Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day the people rose early, and they built there an altar and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Israelites said, “Who in the assembly has not come up from all the tribes of Israel to Yahweh?” For a solemn oath was taken concerning whoever did not come up to Yahweh at Mizpah, saying, “He will certainly be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites had compassion for Benjamin, their relatives, and they said, “Today one tribe is cut off from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: What will we do for them—for the ones being left over—for wives? For we have sworn by Yahweh not to give to them our daughters as wives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked, “Which one is there from the tribes of Israel who did not come up to Yahweh at Mizpah?” And behold, no one came from Jabesh-gilead to the camp, to the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people were counted, and no one was there from the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the congregation sent there twelve thousand men from the troops, and they commanded them, saying, “Go, strike the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead with the edge of the sword, and the women and children.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the thing you will do: you will destroy every man and every woman who had sex with a man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they found among the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead four hundred young virgins who had not had sex with a man, and they brought them to the camp at Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the congregation sent and spoke all this to the descendants of Benjamin who were at the rock of Rimmon, and they assured them they would not be hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Benjamin returned at that time, and they gave to them the women whom they kept alive from Jabesh-gilead; but they were not enough for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people felt sorry for Benjamin because Yahweh weakened the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the elders of the congregation said, “What should we do for the remaining ones for wives, since the women from Benjamin have been destroyed?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “There must be a remnant for Benjamin, so that a tribe will not be blotted out from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we cannot give them wives from our daughters.” (For the Israelites swore, saying, “Cursed be anyone who gives a wife to Benjamin.”)
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “Look, the annual feast of Yahweh is in Shiloh, which is to the north of Bethel, east of the main road that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and south of Lebonah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They instructed the descendants of Benjamin, saying, “Go, lie in ambush in the vineyards,
speaker: Narrator

text: and watch and look; when the daughters of Shiloh dance in the dances, come out from the vineyards and seize for yourselves a wife from the daughters of Shiloh, and go to the land of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if their fathers or their brothers complain to us, we will say to them, ‘Allow us to have them, because we did not capture a wife for each man in the battle, and because you did not give them to them, or else you would have been guilty.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Benjamin did likewise, and they took wives for each of them from the dancers whom they seized, and they went and returned to their territory, and they rebuilt the cities and they lived in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites dispersed from there at that time according to tribe and family; and they went out from there, each one to their own territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days there was no king in Israel; each one did what was right in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator
